awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Novel Carbon-Sequestering Biomaterial for Dropped Ceiling Tiles
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to validate a new, biochar-enriched building material as a ceiling tile product. The plane of ceiling tiles represents a vast, untapped opportunity in combating climate change through carbon sequestration. With the innovation, a proprietary mineral matrix is enriched with 50-80% biochar. Biochar is the resulting charcoal-like residue from   pyrolysis.  This stabilized form of carbon is nearly crystalline and resistant to emissions-causing oxidation. Combined with a proprietary mineral binder, the resulting novel material is non-flammable, ultra lightweight, and biodegradable. As a ceiling tile, it can reduce a building’s embodied carbon in an easily quantifiable way, position the building for carbon sink remuneration, boost the green ratings of the building, help qualify a building for sustainability-linked financing - all without compromising on fire safety standards. This project capacitates an innovation that adds to the nation's toolkit in creating a climate-responsible built environment.

The project innovation is a novel, biogenic, cementitious chemistry composed of plant-based biochar, clay, binding minerals, proprietary catalysts, optional reinforcement fibers and optional pigments. The inclusion of biochar is a major characteristic of the innovation, comprising up to 80% of the material. Unlike carbon stored in plant matter, the ocean or in soil, the carbon atoms of biochar are more resistant to losing electrons and being converted into carbon dioxide, therefore making the innovation a novel solution towards converting the built environment into a "carbon bank".  There are three major questions to resolve: how could varying biochar particle sizes impact tile integrity, can the innovation perform satisfactorily in standard tile dimensions amidst different ambient humidity levels, and can the tiles achieve the Class A fire standard of competing tiles. The iterative experimental protocols will utilize the classic American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) tests used to demonstrate building code compliance in all three of these research areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research conducted through this National Science Foundation-supported project addressed a critical challenge in sustainable building materials: developing a ceiling tile that simultaneously reduces carbon emissions, meets rigorous safety standards, and outperforms existing technologies. The investigation centered on innovative material science approaches to transforming building components from environmental burdens to active carbon sequestration technologies.


The built environment currently faces significant environmental challenges. With global building floor area projected to double by 2060, the construction industry requires transformative solutions to reduce its carbon footprint. Traditional building materials have historically forced architects and developers to compromise between environmental sustainability and performance requirements. The Cast Carbon research sought to develop a material that could resolve this fundamental technological constraint.


The research team developed a novel material composed of a proprietary mineral matrix enriched with 50-80% biochar, derived from pyrolyzed biomass. The investigation focused on comprehensive and de-risking testing across three critical research domains: fire safety performance, design specifications, and biochar material compatibility.


Fire safety testing revealed unprecedented results for a bio-based material. The Cast Carbon tiles achieved Class A fire ratings across multiple formulations, demonstrating zero flame spread and zero smoke development. This finding effectively challenges existing assumptions about the limitations of natural, carbon-sequestering building materials.


With a hemp-enriched version of the material, mechanical performance testing demonstrated substantial improvements over traditional mineral fiber tiles. Hardness measurements reached 1,564 LBF compared to existing materials' 132 LBF, with transversal strength increasing to 290 PSI. These results represent a significant advancement in material performance capabilities.


The carbon sequestration potential proved particularly noteworthy. Each square meter of Cast Carbon tiles can sequester 10 kg of CO2 equivalent. 


The research ultimately developed two distinct product lines: a high-performance, hemp-based ceiling tile system and a biochar-enriched wall tile solution. These innovations represent more than technological advancements; they demonstrate a fundamental reimagining of building materials as active environmental solutions.


Potential applications span multiple critical sectors, including data centers, commercial properties, educational facilities, and healthcare environments. The research provides a promising approach for organizations seeking to meet ambitious sustainability goals while maintaining high-performance standards.


The project's broader impacts extend beyond technical specifications. The proposed materials have potential applications in improving learning environments, enhancing workplace productivity, and supporting sustainable manufacturing practices. By creating opportunities for green collar job development, the research addresses environmental, economic, and social challenges simultaneously.


Most significantly, the research demonstrates that sustainability and high-performance materials are not mutually exclusive. Through systematic scientific investigation and innovative material design, the project provides a framework for developing building components that actively contribute to carbon reduction efforts.


The Cast Carbon research represents a critical step in addressing global challenges related to embodied carbon in the built environment. By challenging existing material science paradigms, the project offers a promising approach to developing more sustainable building technologies.


Supported by the National Science Foundation, this research illustrates the potential of innovative scientific investigation to generate transformative solutions to complex environmental challenges.
